Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Holocene Precipitation Variability and its Relationship to Prehistoric Agriculture and Fires

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will use hydrogen isotope analyses of leaf waxes preserved in sediment cores from three lakes to reconstruct variations in precipitation across the Holocene. Comparing the precipitation data to paleo-ecological evidence in the same sediment cores and to local and regional archaeology will allow the researchers to examine the effects of past droughts on people, and the coupled effects of droughts and human activity on vegetation and fire. The research will contribute to a greater understanding of Holocene environmental change, and provide insight into how prehistoric civilizations responded to drought. The results of this research will be shared as case studies in classes offered by the investigators, including undergraduate courses, summer courses for high school students, and workshops on environmental change offered to middle and high school teachers. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award will provide support to enable a promising student, an Army veteran, to establish a strong independent research career.

Reconstructing the causes of past environmental changes and the degree to which those changes are related to natural variations in the Earth system rather than human impacts requires a signal that is unaffected by anthropogenic landscape modification. Building accurate records of past droughts can be complicated by mixed environmental signals in areas that were heavily influenced by prehistoric people. Variations in hydrogen isotopes in lake sediments reflect changes in precipitation that are unaffected by human activity, and the technique can be used on sediments from lakes that lack biogenic carbonates. The researchers will study hydrogen isotopes in cores in hand from Costa Rica to answer three questions: 1) How do environmental histories differ across ecological zones and gradients of human disturbance?;(2) Can past variations in precipitation explain population shifts apparent in the archaeological record?; and (3) Does reduced precipitation drive fire at both upland and lowland sites, irrespective of human impact? The data developed in this project will contribute to archaeological research and improved fire management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reports from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change predict that Central America and the Caribbean will be hard-hit by climate change, with precipitation reductions affecting the livelihoods of millions of people. Adjacent areas of the southeastern U.S. are also predicted to see significant changes, including increases in so-called "tropical nights" - days in which temperatures never drop below 68 degrees Fahrenheit, even at night. The southeastern U.S. will also be affected by rising sea levels, driven by increasing temperatures and decreasing global ice volumes. Changes in precipitation, temperature, and sea level threaten agriculture and industry, and have the potential to displace millions of people in the U.S. and abroad. Our ability to predict and mitigate these changes relies on understanding the natural range of variation possible in earth-system processes and how humans have responded to past changes in climate. We can develop understanding of natural variation in climate and of human responses to change by studying evidence preserved in lake sediments.

Funded by this dissertation improvement award, Dr. Matthew Kerr completed his dissertation that documents how extreme climate events of the past, such as the Terminal Classic Drought and the Little Ice Age, affected three sites in Costa Rica and how prehistoric people responded to these and other changes in climate.

Building accurate records of paleoclimate from lake sediments is complicated in areas of the world that were heavily influenced by prehistoric human activity, such as forest clearance, because signals of drought can be mixed and confused with signals of human activity in lake watersheds. Working with advisors and co-investigators Drs. Sally Horn and Chad Lane, Dr. Kerr analyzed variations in hydrogen isotopes in leaf waxes preserved in lake sediments, which reflect changes in precipitation that are independent from human activity.

Dr. Kerr used sediment cores from three lakes in different climate regions to identify long-term trends in precipitation across the Holocene (the past 11,700 years) and to compare precipitation trends to vegetation, fire, and human activity, especially during times of global-scale climate events. Sediments from Lago de las Morrenas 1, in the cold highlands that were never permanently occupied by people, revealed 10,000 years of millennial-scale variations in hydroclimate at this lake site, which was dry during the Early Holocene, moist during the Middle Holocene, and then dry over the Late Holocene. Four global-scale climate events are recorded in the Morrenas sediments, including an 8200 BP event, a 5200 BP event, the Terminal Classic Drought, and the Little Ice Age. Laguna Bonillita in the Caribbean lowlands has a 2700-year history of continuous maize agriculture. Isotope data show variations in paleohydrology over the Late Holocene, with drier conditions during the Terminal Classic Drought and the Little Ice Age that match patterns across the wider Caribbean region. In this lowland rainforest environment, maize agriculture benefitted from episodes of drier climate. Laguna Santa Elena in the southern Pacific lowlands has a 2000-year history of maize agriculture. Here, variations in Late Holocene paleohydrology had important consequences for prehistoric people. Santa Elena experienced only minor reductions in rainfall during the Terminal Classic Drought, unlike sites on the Caribbean side of the Isthmus. Additionally, results show that two population collapses inferred to take place during dry periods instead happened during wet intervals at Santa Elena.

Documenting how prehistoric people responded to changes in climate and to extreme climate events of the past, such as the Terminal Classic Drought and the Little Ice Age, is critical to understanding the ability of complex civilizations to adapt to, and to survive, climate change. Dr. Kerr's dissertation research also contributes to archaeological research, to fire management, and to broader efforts to understand past variations in atmospheric drivers of climate change that affected wide areas of Earth, including the southeastern U.S.

Undergraduate students in geography, anthropology, and chemistry at the University of Tennessee gained laboratory experience helping Dr. Kerr with his research. Results of the project were shared in in talks at professional meetings; in university courses taught by Drs. Kerr, Horn, and Lane; and in K-12 outreach, including a summer course for high school students on the Collapse of Civilizations taught by Dr. Kerr.
